Incident.Summary: COMPLAINANT REPORTED A BURGLARY IN PROGRESS, THEN ADJUSTED INCIDENT TO ONLY A THEFT, IN RELATION TO WHAT IS OTHERWISE A DOMESTIC-RELATED ISSUE. SEE NARRATIVE FOR FURTHER.

IncidentSuppNarrative.NarrativeText:
SCENE PROCESSING:

    A list of reported stolen items, provided to me by the complainant, can be found in "Attachments."

    I, Trooper First Class Scott (#7217) of the Maryland State Police, am equipped with a body-worn camera, which was recording during investigation of this incident. 

    TOTAL VALUE STOLEN: $4,859.90
            - See "Attachments" for list of stolen tools. Approximate values provided by complainant.
               The complainant initially estimated roughly $5,000.00. However, further calculation led to the above estimate. 

NARRATIVE:

    On June 6, 2023, at approximately 0628 hours, I, Trooper First Class Scott (#7217) of the Maryland State Police, was dispatched to the Lion Xpress located at 1252 Jacob Tome Memorial Highway, Port Deposit, Maryland in relation to what was initially reported as a burglary in-progress. However, further investigation revealed the issue is more accurately a theft (if anything). I arrived on scene at approximately 0635 hours. 

    Upon arrival, I met the complainant, Joshua David Miller (W/M; DOB: 09/21/1990). When I met Miller, he told me he got out of jail at approximately 0300 hours on the morning of June 6, 2023, and he was in jail for about a week. He returned home to 1441 Belvidere Road, Port Deposit, Maryland, and reported seeing an Edward John Adkins (W/M; DOB: 01/03/1992) subject inside the residence. Miller was initially claiming Adkins made unauthorized entry to the house. 

    However, upon further questioning, I learned Miller stays at the residence with his girlfriend, named as "Jessica." Miller went on to tell me he believes "Jessica" has been having an affair with the Edward Adkins subject. Considering what Miller said, it seemed to be likely Adkins was permitted by Jessica to be inside the residence, making this issue not a burglary. I also recall Miller saying something along the lines of wanting to "hurt" Adkins (which can be heard about nine minutes and fifty-five seconds into the body-camera video). This caused me to suspect Miller's reported burglary was more the result of a vendetta he may have against Adkins. 

    Miller went on to report that his vehicle, a 2007 Nissan Maxima (VIN: 1N4BA41E37C841056), had been entered and cleared of several tools, which he claimed to have been stolen by Adkins. Miller also told me he thinks the cameras attached to the residence were not functioning when the supposed theft occurred. 

    It was also thought at the time that Adkins may have been in jail during the supposed incident. When asked about this, Miller went on to say he "thought" he saw Adkins at the residence.

    Considering everything Miller told me, and his apparent declining confidence that he did in fact see Adkins, I referred him to the Cecil County Commissioner's Office for criminal charges. I gave him a victim/witness pamphlet with the case number, my name, rank, and identification number, and the Maryland State Police North East Barrack non-emergency telephone line. After considering Miller's story as well, it seems based on his account he waited over three hours to report what he claimed was a burglary/rogue and vagabond/theft incident at his residence. 

    I then made my way over to 1441 Belvidere Road to inspect the would-be crime scene. I made contact with the homeowner, who identified herself as "Carol" (W/F). Carol answered the front door when I knocked. Carol told me that, as far as she was aware, there was no burglary at the residence. She also claimed to not know anything about a theft involving the Nissan Maxima Miller claimed to be his. 

    The Nissan Maxima was checked with Miller's permission by Trooper First Class M. Hughes (#7111). The tools Miller claimed were stolen were not found inside. However, inspection of the surrounding area revealed what appeared to be at least part of a welding tool (a welding tool is coincidentally part of the list of stolen items). 

    While on scene, I instructed Carol to contact police if any issues arise with Miller returning home. I told her this because Miller requested I not notify "Jessica" that Miller was returning home. I found Miller's request strange, so I thought it prudent to at least ask the homeowner to contact police if problems arise.  

    I also discovered the registration plate attached to the Nissan Maxima (Maryland 55K792) was registered to a 2002 International Tractor/Trailer, owned by the United Parcel Service. As the Nissan Maxima was obviously not of that make/model and most likely not owned by the United Parcel Service, I seized the registration plate from the vehicle to investigate whether United Parcel Service wished to report the registration plate stolen. 

    I called United Parcel Service at approximately 0805 hours. After a few telephone calls with them from the North East Barrack recorded telephone line, I learned the registered vehicle for 55K792 has been disabled since approximately May 29, 2020. I spoke to a "Melissa Bentler" subject from United Parcel Service about this. Therefore, it was unable to be determined if the registration plate was actually stolen or simply found after its registered vehicle was disabled. As a result, I turned the registration plate in to the Maryland State Police North East Barrack so that it may be appropriately returned to the Motor Vehicle Administration. 

    I request this case be suspended pending an application for charges from Miller or additional supporting information regarding Miller's allegations. 

    All events occurred in Cecil County, Maryland.
